instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
This machine was sent in as not working after a power surge. When I plug my chargers in I get no light at all and no fan spin even after plugging in a know good io board/cable. On the board I see some probe points that look discolored but I don't see any corrosion anywhere nor any damaged components so I can't say for sure there was liquid damage. A few of those discolored probe points were around the SMC and <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and other places.
There is no voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and no short to ground on either of those lines. Here are some other measurements I took on the DCIN line.

<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and Pins 1/2 of J7000 - fluctuates from 0.19v-0.47v
<RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> in diode mode - 0.70v - Resistance 100kohms

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> 0v on both sides and no short to ground

I don't have a fake chinese charger to test and see if it turns on with it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
What is the first voltage to check if there is no green light?

Oh, I see no 3V42. Do you have a bench PSU to put 16V on DCIN?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message: Okay I used my r mete ps305-dm power supply and tried injecting 16v into pin 1 of J7000 but the highest it would let the voltage go up to was 1.6v. The current was showing 5.02 Amps or mA it didn't specify which one and a red light was on the current side which I believe meant that was the highest it could go up to. Even with the charger plugged in the voltage would show around 1.3v on PPDCIN

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message: Do I now need to tell you to find what is heating up?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
Start injecting with lower voltage; go up from 1V for example.
If your supply shows 5A and gets blocked will not inject anything.
Put amp at max and increase voltage maintaining current less than 5A; if this is the limit of your supply...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message: I found that <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> was gettting really hot and that is where the short was. I replaced it with one from a donor and when I plugged the charger in still no light and DCIN voltage is around .1v so I went to inject voltage and <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> was getting very hot again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> has no pin connected to ground.
Something more is shorted to ground after it.
You probably burnt it again.
Find the short before power up the board again.
Maybe <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
The <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> was not getting very hot but it did feel somewhat hot but I figure that could have been because <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> is on the other side of the board and the heat came from there.
I couldn't find any other component that was getting hot except for <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> so I just removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and put 16v on that line but my power supply showed 0Amps going through it. I then cut off the power supply and plugged in the charger but there was still only 0.1v on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
I already told you start with lower voltage!
Increase voltage maintaining under the current limit of your supply...
Did you check <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
Okay I put <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> back on the board and put 1v on that line and slowly went up to 1.6v which was the limit before 5 Amps was reached. I wasn't able to find any other component that was getting unusually hot. I even poured some alcohol to see what gets hot and sizzles away but nothing was sizzling when I put the alcohol on the board like <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> was not feeling too hot or burning the alcohol off fast.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message: The 5A is just passing through <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and heating it up. I bet PPBUS is shorted or there is a short after <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>. That 5A is going somewhere.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
Pin 2 of F7140(<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) in diode mode was 0.159v and the resistance to ground was showing 445ohms.

I measured <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> in diode mode. Pin 1 was 0.61v and on the board there are 3 pins above it but on the boardview it doesn't show those 3 pins. All three of those pins measured 0v to ground in diode mode.
When I checked those same pins on <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> on a donor board I have they were showing about 0.61v in diode mode.

What do I check to find a short after <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message: 445 Ohm on PPBUS is no good but not enough of a short to pull 5A. You need to find a real short, that 5A is going somewhere.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
So I thought it might have been <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR> that was getting hot but I couldn't tell if that heat was coming from <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> being close by so I just removed <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>&<CAPACITOR>C7131</CAPACITOR>. Before removing in diode mode both sides of <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C7131</CAPACITOR> were 0v to ground and after removing them Pin 1 is 0.57v in diode mode. With those components removed from the board I tried injecting 1v to the DCIN line but no current was going through.

Should I put another <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>/31 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> on the board? I just don't want to kill those components again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> short to ground?
If yes, check <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>/31 and <CAPACITOR>C7135</CAPACITOR>-37.
No other reason, as you have 0.159 at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; which is correct value there...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power after surge
threads.message:
Okay I put a new <CAPACITOR>C7130</CAPACITOR>/31 on the board and now it turns on and I was able to boot my USB OS. The battery is not being recognized and shows the X. I plugged in one of my non working batteries I had laying around and it was recognized but wasn't charging which is likely because of that battery so I will order a new battery and this should be fixed.
This can be marked as solved.

Thanks [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER]
